abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Irrigation Subsector II (O&M)
            Project in Indonesia. The objectives of the project were to
            continue: (a) strengthening cost recovery, encouraging
            efficient use of water resources, and supporting the
            turnover of small public irrigation schemes to water
            users' associations (WUAs); (b) supporting
            institutional development; and (c) improving the physical,
            programming, budgeting and institutional aspects of O&M,
            so that the effectiveness of existing systems could be
            sustained. Bank’s performance was satisfactory. The Borrower
            has generally performed satisfactorily. The key lessons
            learned were as follows (a) good performance would be
            achieved more efficiently if the institutional structure
            under the Bupati and the process and procedures for
            implementing the Irrigation Service Fee (ISF) program were
            reviewed and strengthened; (ii) most construction quality
            deficiencies are due to lack of compliance with existing
            construction specifications and standards; there is a need
            to establish accountability; (iii) expensive groundwater
            development is unlikely to be economically viable if it is
            used to irrigate low value crops with low cropping
            intensity; and (iv) efficient water allocation to improve
            water resources management requires an effective long-term
            institutional arrangement.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Irrigation Subsector
            (O&M) Project is the second phase of a long-term program
            aimed at supporting the basic goals outlined in the
            Government's Policy Statement for the irrigation
            subsector as well as the Government's policies on
            decentralization.  The project will support:  (a) the
            collection of the irrigation service fee over about 700,000
            ha and the turnover of small public irrigation schemes
            covering about 130,000 ha to Water Users Associations
            (WUAs); (b) institutional strengthening by providing project
            and construction quality control, improving system design
            and operating procedures, establishing basin-focused water
            operations on a pilot basis, supporting WUA establishment
            and strengthening activities of training and community
            organization, instituting a programming and monitoring
            system and improving environmental assessment capabilities;
            and (c) minor works related to: (i) the irrigation and
            swamps schemes where only deferred maintenance and minor
            systems modification is needed; (ii) the introduction of
            efficient and sustained levels of O&M funding,
            procedures and related activities so that by the end of the
            project period, 1.7 million ha of irrigation land and
            170,000 ha of swamps schemes will be under the
            Bank-supported program; and (iii) completion of selected
            activities under the First irrigation subsector project.
